author: Advait
title: Deqree: Certificate Validation 🎓
description: India has an increasing problem of counterfeit degrees with no reliable way for recruiters to verify an applicant's educational credentials.

assessments.note: The Indian government has a  National Academic Depository, which is to under the University Grants Commission for authentication of academic documents. There is a need for a top-down approach to this complex problem. What has been achieved in Ethiopia is the correct model. It is not a "nonavailability of app" problem. The proposed app is not likely to be used in a general sense in India since there is no clarity on the use of cryptocurrency-backed blockchain projects in India.
assessments.reply: The Reviewer doesn't realize that the NAD requires the candidate to provide a set of private information to the verifier and also needs to be pre-registered for that service to work. On top of that the NAD is slow and time-taking. Regarding the lack of government clarity, according to current laws blockchain based projects are legal and in fact encouraged. Also our project does not require the end users to deal with the blockchain and they won't even realize they are using one.

assessments.note: The proposal hits on a trust problem that may be addressed by blockchain technology, and the paper included an analysis on how big the problem is.

The proposal addresses the Challenge's goal of using metadata for tamper-resistant documentation. However, the proposal is silent on how users of the system would verify that the metadata was uploaded by an authorized university—it appears that the process would involve trusting that the Deqree serivce has properly verified the credenials of the submitting official at the university, but that contradicts the "no need for a central authority" requirement in the project description.. The proposal would be stronger if it leveraged established trust frameworks such as the W3C Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) or Atala Prism.

Proposers are 5 undergraduate students. It is not clear they have the technical capabilities to produce the project. The project relies on the universities uploading the data. They have not provided any information on how they intend to convince any universities to come on board.
assessments.reply: We are constantly learning and constantly building. We also have applied to several universities' Incubation cells and our application is under review.

assessments.note: The reference Github repository is blank and the proposers have not claimed and prior experience in large-scale secure software or blockchain development. The major component of government policy management and legal requirements have not been consider in the road map.
assessments.reply: The Github account currently has only private repos which would be public once we launch on testnet. Yes, we might not have significant experience but the challenge promises us meetings with IOHK experts which will help us identify and overcome our shortcomings.

assessments.note: while the team is talented with an array of languages, none of them are block chain and there is a concern whether they will be able to deliver. In addition, there is no discussion on how to provide provable authority for the original issuance of the degree on chain, revocation, privacy, and administration. this could be achieved with the use of Digital ID. The problem is one of the better defined ones on Catalyst, however the solution is lacking.
assessments.reply: Yes, we are good with quite a few languages and we have the right knowledge of blockchain fundamentals as can be infered from our paper. With IOHK announcing that they plan to release a developer SDK for atala prism soon, we strongly believe that we have the capabilities to utilize it properly for our needs.

assessments.note: The proposers possess the requisite experience to successfully execute the project, but the plan is not presented as a staged set of intermediate activities or milestones. Thus, the proposal is more descriptive of the technologies that would be employed, rather that prescriptive of the path that development would take. The proposal lacks a plan for client engagement and testing, but that would be critical to adoption: a service-design or agile methodology would have been valuable for this.

Without any universities coming on board, they have no data. Would this project be considered a success if they build the software but don't populate it with any data or link to any university systems.
assessments.reply: We believe that blockchain based solutions won't get mainstream adoption overnight. What we are creating is a platform which we hope will serve as a reference for others who want to build a similar identity based use case. Our efforts will make it easier for the next set of proposers to have a project to look back at and then improve and build upon our designs.

assessments.note: The problem of fake degrees is serious and the Indian government is alive to the issue and has taken major steps in stemming it. The issue of regulatory compliance in the case of users' private data is a serious problem that has not been considered in the proposal.
While the project doesn't provide concrete goals, there are references to the potential size of market through out the proposal. the Key metric is clear and it is degrees on chain.

The proposal contains the basic information that would be required to to measure success, but it lacks the intermediate timeline that would be needed to measure progress towards the final goal. The project would need a roadmap if progress were to be audited efficiently.

solution: Develop a cost effective dApp platform to validate certificate credentials using transaction metadata and a native token.
experience: We are a team of 5 Indian Undergrad students with a combined experience in Python, C++, SQL, HTML, JavaScript and learning more everyday.
